{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3264370,"name":"Matthew Ferrell","username":"thatonemf5503","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatonemf5503/{size}/188318_2.png","created_at":"2023-12-13T16:50:27.863Z","cooked":"

We’re trying to go for swerve code next competition, and for practice, I used the zero to autonomous coding for swerve and changed it to work with the MK4i system. It worked at first, but needed some tuning to be done, which I tried. However, when I changed the code, the bot started to go haywire with the slightest touch to the joystick(see video). When I tried changing it back and deploying, I got the same outcome.
We’re using CanAndCoders from redux robotics connected through the sparkmax interface. We are also using neos for the swerve. I’ve tried looking at other posts, but nothing seems to work.
below I have the video in question, and the links to our swerve code, and the zero to autonomous code.(I had to do some translating for vscode to let me deploy)

github.com

//github.com/SeanSun6814/FRC0ToAutonomous/tree/master/%236%20Swerve%20Drive%20Auto

drive.google.com

IMG_8934.MOV

Google Drive file.

GitHub

GitHub - Team-5503/offseason: this is hell

this is hell. Contribute to Team-5503/offseason development by creating an account on GitHub.

Edit: the repo preview is using an old description from what I see, it should now say “this is something I need help with.”

Sounds like you may have answered your own question. PID loop tuning can be sensitive and behave quite differently on blocks vs on the floor. Beyond that with modified constants if encoder ticks don’t match what the gear ratio is then you get this behavior as motors slam full forward and reverse, blasting past setpoints and trying to recover. Not good on the mechanical system.

I recommend playing with things by hand to see if values are in the expected ranges, reducing max power, and ideally graphing things to identify what values are not behaving as you may expect.

Unfortunately there is no one magical set of values that someone can give you by looking at your code, I wish it were that easy.

I understand the frustration, probably best practice to not vent that in the repo description though.

My fault, I created the repo when I was extremely frustrated with the code and working with git bash, which was a few weeks ago.
I’ve already changed it, but I might have to edit the post for it come through on chief delphi

Although when I did change back the values, the result was still the same
It may be a compiling error or the roborio acting up, but I have a feeling it may be the variables or possibly the code that is meant for the drive motors to switch to reverse when the wheels need to turn more than 90 degrees.
There may be a better way to do calculations like that, or it may be better just to remove it all together
